Resource.ResourceName: Indoor Air Quality in Tribal Communities
Resource.DescriptionText: American Indian and Native Alaskan communities may be disproportionately affected by health problems associated with poor indoor air quality, such as lung cancer. However, many actions can be taken to improve IAQ in tribal communities to slowly begin to change those statistics. This website can help you improve IAQ in your tribal community. You can find information to educate your community about the simple actions they can take to improve their IAQ and protect their health, as well as examples of how other tribes have created sustainable community outreach and education programs.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use resource for communities.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Website that can help improve air quality in your tribal community. Information to educate community members about simple actions they can take to improve IAQ.

Resource.ResourceName: Industrial Waste Management: A Guide to Best Practices
Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIM / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA has created the Guide for Industrial Waste Management, a one-stop resource for comprehensive and informative tools to help manage industrial waste in your state, company, or community. Available in CDROM, this Guide is the result of a collaborative effort among state and federal regulators, industry, and environmentalists to provide practical information and training on industrial waste management.
Resource.CommentsText: Order form for the waste management guide.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource for comprehensive and informative tools to help manage industrial waste in a specific state, company, or community.

Resource.ResourceName: Interactive Map of RCRA Corrective Action Sites in the Mid-Atlantic Region
Resource.DescriptionText: An interactive map of RCRA Corrective Action sites in the Mid-Atlantic region. Use the pan and zoom features of Microsoft Virtual Earth to move the map around and/or to zoom in on a particular location.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use interactive map.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Interactive map of RCRA corrective action sites in the Mid-Atlantic region.

Resource.ResourceName: Interactive Primer for Water and Wastewater Utilities and Toolbox
Resource.DescriptionText: Resource that will help users respond to both current and future challenges of the 21st century in regards to drinking water and Wastewater.
Resource.CommentsText: Good trained and educational walk through tool.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that will help users respond to both current and future challenges of the 21st century in regards to drinking water and Wastewater.

Resource.DescriptionText: Database that features over 530 Best Management Practices studies, performance analysis results, tools for use in BMP Performance studies, monitoring guidance, and other study related publications.
Resource.CommentsText: Database with research materials based on specific locations. Users may have issue finding materials for the proper location.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Database featuring over 530 best management practice studies, performance results, tools, monitoring guidance, and other studies.

Resource.DescriptionText: Know your H20 is a free application available on the iTunes and Android App stores. Know Your H2O? helps you to identify the existing and historic environmental hazards in your community. They are working with a national environmental database search company to offer a report to help you understand your homes or your future homes environmental health status within a community. They are doing this by taking a snapshot of the current and historic environmental concerns and hazards in the community and a review of select criminal activity.
Resource.CommentsText: Application is free. Requires a smart phone. Know Your H2O? is an educational tool that can help you diagnose the problem with your water. This app will lead you through a series of questions to pinpoint the issues with your water. You can reach your diagnosis through describing symptoms that are effecting your home, your health, or the water itself. Once you receive your diagnosis result(s), the app is designed to educate you by displaying full lists of symptoms, causes, and solutions, as well as links to other educational sources. The app will then show you various testing kit options specifically designed to treat those results. If the problem is more extensive and in depth testing is required, Know Your H2O? will also connect you with featured local professionals.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Mobile application that helps users identify the existing and historic environmental hazards in your community.

Resource.DescriptionText: The intent of this document is to establish better quality indoor air in the building after construction and during occupancy. Conduct baseline IAQ testing using protocols consistent with the methods listed in Table 1 for all occupied spaces. Use current versions of ASTM standard methods, EPA compendium methods, or ISO methods, as indicated.
Resource.CommentsText: LEED certified, or knowledgeable professionals will need to use this tool. Helps assess indoor air quality.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource to establish better indoor air quality in a building after construction as well as during occupancy.

Resource.DescriptionText: The LT2ESWTR Microbial Toolbox - Version 2, updated in early 2007, is a Web tool that can help utilities meet requirements of the Long-Term 2 Enhanced Surface Water Treatment Rule by determining which treatment is most suitable for their water treatment plant. The Toolbox serves as a decision tree tool that will guide you through several steps to attain Cryptosporidium credits associated with the LT2ESWTR.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides an easy to follow wizard and guidance on the rule. Not updated often but still a good starting point. Would need to validated the data is accurate.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: A web tool that can help utilities meet requirements of LT2 Enhanced Surface Water Treatment Rule by determining which

Resource.DescriptionText: Provides information on Landfills.
Resource.CommentsText: Basic Information on Landfills.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides information on Landfills.

Resource.ResourceName: Leak Detection and Repair: A Best Practices Guide
Resource.DescriptionText: Leaking equipment, such as valves, pumps, and connectors, are a large source of emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and volatile hazardous air pollutants (VHAPs) The Leak Detection and Repair: A Best Practices Guide- is intended for use by regulated entities, such as petroleum refineries and chemical manufacturing facilities, as well as compliance inspectors. The guide details some of the problems identified with leak detection and repair (LDAR) programs. It focuses on Method 21 requirements, and describes the practices that can be used to increase the effectiveness of an LDAR program.
Resource.CommentsText: Beneficial tool for operators and managers.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Best practices guide for leak detection and repair.

Resource.DescriptionText: User reported waste around the world. Includes images and descriptions. Interactive map. Easy to use.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use map to add your own data or to locate potential waste areas in a region.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: User reported waste around the world. Includes images and descriptions. Interactive map. Easy to use.

Resource.ResourceName: Mapping Solid Waste: Roadmap for Data Collection
Resource.DescriptionText: Presentation that speaks of the importance of data collection. Overall roadmap for data collection and the information required before data collection can begin.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Presentation that speaks of the importance of data collection. Overall roadmap for data collection and the information required before data collection can begin.

Resource.ResourceName: Microbial and Disinfection Byproducts (MDBP) Training Site
Resource.DescriptionText: This site is your one-stop for information about past and upcoming training for the implementation of the Stage 2, LT2 and Ground Water rules. On this site you will find information about Webcasts, train the trainer sessions, and other training opportunities designed to help you with the implementation of the Stage 2, LT2 and Ground Water rules as well as the older rules if applicable to you.
Resource.CommentsText: It can be accessed from the Compliance Main page. We might not want to include separate. Seems dated and is pretty much focused on submission of data vs any compliance help.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides information about past and upcoming training for the implementation of the Stage2, LT2, and Ground Water rules.

Resource.DescriptionText: A simple form builder for mobile devices to allow users to manage and create forms for inspections and other utility data collection.
Resource.CommentsText: Only include as an example of a free mobile form builder that utilities could use to build inspection or O&M forms. This can be used by utilities to build forms or websites. We can include more of these technologies if this seems relevant.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: A simple form builder for mobile devices to allow users to manage and create forms for inspections and other utility data collection.

Resource.DescriptionText: New technologies are changing the way we monitor pollution in the environment. EPA is studying innovative technologies that will measure nutrient pollution in the air and water.
Resource.CommentsText: Information on next generation monitoring and research.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: New technologies are changing the way we monitor pollution in the environment. EPA is studying innovative technologies that will measure nutrient pollution in the air and water.

Resource.ResourceName: Moving Toward Sustainability: Sustainable and Effective Practices
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA is now issuing Moving Toward Sustainability: Sustainable and Effective Practices for Creating Your Own Water Utility Roadmap. The purposes of this document is to assist utilities move toward sustainability by implementing proven practices over time at a pace consistent with their needs and the needs of the communities they serve. The document includes checklists and recommendations on moving towards sustainability.
Resource.CommentsText: Although a guidance document it is very easy to read and follow and address new topics and ways a small/medium/large utility can move into the 21st century. Great step by step process. Might be an interesting tool that could help work like Equifax or other scoring scenarios to show if you do this your utility can become more sustainable and improve operations and compliance.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that provides assistance and information on sustainable and effective practices for creating a water utility road map.

Resource.ResourceName: Municipal Solid Waste Generation, Recycling, and Disposal in the United States: Facts and Figures
Resource.DescriptionText: Provides a report based on date from 1995 to 2012. Each report has a series of facts and figures in relation to MSW Generation
Resource.CommentsText: Ability to compare facts and figures. Data is useful and may help in planning.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides a report based on date from 1995 to 2012. Each report has a series of facts and figures in relation to MSW Generation

Resource.DescriptionText: Geographically view TRI facilities in a selected area and obtain summary-level facility information including facility rankings, quantities of chemicals released and associated potential health affects, and compliance data. This simple tool designed for mobile devices in English and Spanish.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool to view TRI facilities in a selected area while obtaining summary level facility information.

Resource.DescriptionText: MyWATERS Mapper dynamically displays snapshots of EPA Office of Water program data. This version of MyWATERS Mapper depicts the status of NPDES permits for each State; summary information from the Clean Watershed Needs Survey; and water quality assessments. Future versions will include other Office of Water Program Snapshots. MyWATERS Mapper also contains water-related geographic themes such as 12-digit watersheds, the national stream network known as the National Hydrography Dataset, and other water-related map layers. MyWATERS Mapper enables you to create customized maps at national and local scales.
Resource.CommentsText: Requires shockwave in order to operate.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Dynamically displays snapshots of EPA Office of Water program data.

Resource.DescriptionText: Various application forms that are applicable to a number of NPDES program areas.
Resource.CommentsText: Forms required for NPDES permitting.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Various application forms that are applicable to a number of NPDES program areas.

Resource.DescriptionText: FAQ for NPDES with a series of topics: Permitting, TMDL, Water Quality based Permit Limits for Recreational Water Quality Data.
Resource.CommentsText: Basic FAQ regarding NDPES.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: FAQ for NPDES with a series of topics: Permitting, TMDL, Water Quality based Permit Limits for Recreational Water Quality Data.

Resource.DescriptionText: Contains basic information on the major features and elements of the NPDES permit program. The information in this section will be most useful to state and tribal officials, interested citizens, and others with an interest in the details of the NPDES program. This information is broadly applicable to all NPDES permits and programs, including concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs), pesticide discharges, combined sewer overflows (CSOs), pretreatment, sanitary sewer overflows (SSOs), stormwater and whole effluent toxicity (WET).
Resource.CommentsText: Website provides reference to all of EPA's Wastewater Regs and gives a starting point. If additional information is needed we could pull out specific regs and link to them. This would relevant to stormwater as well.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Contains basic information on the major features and elements of the NPDES permit program.

Resource.DescriptionText: The NPDES permitting program offers training courses, workshops, and webinars to explain the regulatory framework and technical considerations of the NPDES permit program. These courses are designed for permit writers, dischargers, EPA officials, and other interested parties.
Resource.CommentsText: Training materials for NPDES.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Training courses, workshops, and webinars that explain the regulatory framework and technical considerations of the NPDES permit program.

Resource.DescriptionText: Provides a variety amount of resources in regards to conservation and alternative energy. Weekly articles, guides are used to help the user understand more about alternative energy.
Resource.CommentsText: Resource
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides a variety amount of resources in regards to conservation and alternative energy. Weekly articles, guides are used to help the user understand more about alternative energy.

Resource.ResourceName: National Air Quality Site Assessment Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: The National Air Quality Site Assessment Tool (NAQSAT) has been developed for the voluntary use of livestock producers and their advisors or consultants. It is intended to provide assistance to livestock and poultry producers in determining the areas in their operations where there are opportunities to make changes that result in reduced air emissions. Air emissions research from livestock production systems is increasing every year. NAQSAT is based on the most accurate, credible data currently available regarding mitigation strategies for air emissions of ammonia, methane, volatile organic compounds, hydrogen sulfide, particulates, and odor.
Resource.CommentsText: Will be valuable for specific rural communities.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool developed for the voluntary use of livestock producers and their advisors to provide assistance to producers in determining areas in the operations where they can reduce air emissions.

Resource.ResourceName: National Environmental Services Center Drinking Water and Wastewater Financial Assistance, Tools, Database and Technical Assistance
Resource.DescriptionText: For over 35 years, the National Environmental Services Center (NESC) has helped thousands of small, rural communities with their drinking water, wastewater, environmental training, infrastructure resilience, and utility management needs--leading them to solutions to the problems they face. The site includes technical assistance phone numbers and ask the experts email and phone number. In addition it includes 2 listservs for drinking and wastewater. The site has migrated to Facebook and can be found at https://www.facebook.com/NationalEnvironmentalServicesCenter
Resource.CommentsText: This is a large website that provides numerous resources. The site has most recently moved to updating via Facebook. Much of the site material is outdated and they are most focused on technical assistance vs tool development.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides a vast number of different resources to communities in order to better understand and manage the drinking water and wastewater issues of today.

Resource.ResourceName: National Oil and Hazardous Substance Contingency Plan (NCP) Overview.
Resource.DescriptionText: The National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan, more commonly called the National Contingency Plan or NCP, is the federal government's blueprint for responding to both oil spills and hazardous substance releases. The NCP is the result of efforts to develop a national response capability and promote coordination among the hierarchy of responders and contingency plans.
Resource.CommentsText: Overview discussing spills and information.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Federal government's blueprint for responding to both oil and hazardous substance spills.

Resource.DescriptionText: The National Response System (NRS) routinely and effectively responds to a wide range of oil and hazardous substance releases. It is a multi-layered system of individuals and teams from local, state, and federal agencies, industry, and other organizations. These groups share expertise and resources to ensure that cleanup activities are timely, efficient, and minimize threats to human health and the environment.
Resource.CommentsText: Recommended in times of emergency.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that responds to a wide range of oil and hazardous substance releases.

Resource.DescriptionText: Desktop application that estimates the annual amount of rainwater and frequency of runoff from a specific site anywhere in the United States (including Puerto Rico). Estimates are based on local soil conditions, land cover, and historic rainfall records. Designed to be used by anyone interested in reducing runoff from a property including site developers, landscape architects, urban planners, and homeowners.
Resource.CommentsText: Website provides training materials and information on the application. Calculator accesses several national databases that provide soil, topography, rainfall, and evaporation information for the chosen site.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Application that estimates the annual amount of rainwater and frequency of runoff from a specific site.

Resource.DescriptionText: Resource that provides information on a variety different types of disasters that may occur. Drought, earthquakes, heat, floods, hurricanes, landslides, and weather.
Resource.CommentsText: Basic information depending on the type of natural disaster. Informs users of what to expect and how to prepare.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that provides information on a variety different types of disasters that may occur. Drought, earthquakes, heat, floods, hurricanes, landslides, and weather.

Resource.DescriptionText: Traditionally, air pollution is measured by expensive, stationary and complex air-monitoring instrumentation. Only a few organizations, like federal, state and some industries, typically collect data of such high quality. Even so, this limits the amount of environmental monitoring data that is often available for exposure and health assessments. As air quality management problems become more complex, there is a need for enhanced air quality and exposure monitoring capabilities.
Resource.CommentsText: Informational, EPA, Education
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides research and information on air quality management problems as well as next generation measuring techniques.

Resource.DescriptionText: Provides a list of laws and regulations for non-hazardous waste.
Resource.CommentsText: Laws and Regulations.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides a list of laws and regulations for non-hazardous waste.

Resource.ResourceName: Open Announcement for Competitive Grant Opportunities
Resource.DescriptionText: Announcements of grant opportunities offered by different parties.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Announcements of grant opportunities offered by different parties.
Resource.TopicText: Emerging Technologies, Issues and Topics|Finance and Grants

Resource.ResourceName: Open Data: U.S. Energy Information Administration
Resource.DescriptionText: The U.S. Energy Information Administration is committed to enhancing the value of its free and open data by making it available through an Application Programming Interface (API) and open data tools to better serve our customers. The data in the API is also available in bulk file, in Excel via the add-in, and via widgets that embed interactive data vizualizations of EIA data on any website. By making EIA data available in machine-readable formats, the creativity in the private, the non-profit, and the public sectors can be harnessed to find new ways to innovate and create value-added services powered by public data.
Resource.CommentsText: API provided for a series of different data sets regarding energy consumption.

Resource.DescriptionText: Program for predicating polluting particle passage through pits, puddles and ponds. This model predicts the generation and transport of stormwater runoff pollutants in urban watersheds. Continuous water-balance and mass-balance calculations are performed on a user-defined system consisting of the following elements: watersheds; devices; particle classes; water quality components.
Resource.CommentsText: May have compatibility issues.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Predicts polluting particle passage through pits, puddles and ponds.

Resource.DescriptionText: The NPDES permit writers' manual (EPA-833-K-10-001) provides a comprehensive overview of the framework of the NPDES program. It also serves as one of the principal training tools to help permit writers develop legally defensible and enforceable NPDES permits.
Resource.CommentsText: Manual for permit writing requirements.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides a comprehensive overview of the framework of NPDES program.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIM / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: The purpose of this tool is to prioritize your water distribution and transmission pipes for renewal projects. This prioritization will identify the set of pipes most at risk for failure and with the greatest cost-based consequences for inclusion in your capital improvement program (CIP).
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for CIP, especially for utilities that are not using an off the shelf Asset Management Tool.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool used to prioritize water distribution and transmission pipes for renewal projects. Will identify the set of pipes most at risk for failure with a cost based assessment.

Resource.DescriptionText: This publication answers common questions about indoor air pollutants and discusses ways to reduce or eliminate the problems. For additional information about radon, contact the Clemson University Housing Institute or your County Extension Office for copies of "A Citizen's Guide to Radon," "How to Reduce Radon Levels in Your Home," and "Home Buyers and Sellers Guide to Radon."
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use resouce that gives more information on indoor air quality issues. Provides a list of contaminants and their description.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that answers common questions about indoor air pollutants and discusses ways to reduce or eliminate the problems.

Resource.DescriptionText: The Resilience and Adaptation in New England (RAINE) database is a collection of vulnerability, resilience and adaptation reports, plans and webpages at the state, regional and community level.
Resource.AcronymText: Resilience and Adaptation in New England

Resource.DescriptionText: RETIGO can be used by anyone to explore the data that they collected. To collect the data, monitoring equipment is needed and ranges in price from ten dollar sensors up to professional grade equipment costing tens of thousands of dollars.EPA's Next Generation Air Measuring sitehas an array of information on emerging technologies for air monitoring.
Resource.CommentsText: Data entry and map for viewing monitoring sensors. Many of which are next generation.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Data entry platform for air monitoring equipment.

Resource.ResourceName: Reducing Global Health Risks through Mitigation of Short-Lived Climate Pollutants: Scoping Report for Policymakers
Resource.DescriptionText: Short-lived climate pollutants (SLCPs), including black carbon, methane, and ozone, are responsible for a substantial fraction of climate change as well as for a significant proportion of air-pollution related deaths and diseases that kill some 7 million people per year.
Resource.CommentsText: Publication
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resources on climate pollutants.

Resource.ResourceName: Regional and State Indoor Air Quality Contact Information
Resource.DescriptionText: Each EPA Regional Office is responsible within its states for the execution of the Agency's programs. To get regional information about your EPA Regional Office relating to indoor air quality issues (e.g., radon, indoor air quality, asthma, mold, IAQ Tools for Schools, etc.), click on your region in the map below, or choose your region in the pull-down menu below. Provides the contact information based on EPA regional reps.
Resource.CommentsText: Contact Information.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Map that provides resources on specific EPA regional information on indoor air quality issues.

Resource.DescriptionText: The Clean Air Act is a statute written by Congress that gives EPA the authority to establish regulations, policy, and guidance to protect air quality. This page provides links to some of EPA's air pollution rules and regulations.

Resource.ResourceName: Renewable Energy Ready Home Solar Site Assessment Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: The Renewable Energy Ready Home Solar Site Assessment Tool is intended to guide home builders in assessing whether a new home has the proper physical orientation to support a future installation of a solar energy system. This tool evaluates the proposed site's solar resource potential based on a series of known factors about the home at the time of construction, such as the home's location and anticipated shading effects at the proposed site. New homes that are found to provide a suitable installation environment are considered good candidates to be outfitted by the builder with the structural and system components needed to support the cost effective installation of a future renewable energy system.
Resource.CommentsText: Assessment tool provides basic information relating to your location and roof angles on solar energy capacity.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool intended to guide home builders in assessing whether a new home has the proper physical orientation to support a future installation of a solar energy system.

Resource.ResourceName: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Orientation Manual
Resource.DescriptionText: This manual provides introductory information on the solid and hazardous waste management programs under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). Designed for EPA and state staff, members of the regulated community, and the general public who wish to better understand RCRA, this document constitutes a review of the RCRA program and is not a substitute for RCRA or its implementing regulations.
Resource.CommentsText: manual/document for RCRA Orientation.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Manual that provides introductory information on the solid and hazardous waste management programs under RCRA.

Resource.DescriptionText:
"Water Utility Response On-The-Go is an innovative tool that consolidates information and tools that water utility operators and their response partners may need during an emergency. The tool is ideal for small systems that lack a large support network in place when natural disasters strike. Water Utility Response On-The-Go allows users to accomplish the following:
identify and contact emergency response partners monitor local and national severe weather conditions review and complete incident-specific checklists; and populate save and email both generic damage assessment forms and FEMA incident command system form."
Resource.CommentsText: New tool for mobile Emergency Preparedness. Great tool to help utilities ready for emergency situations and help meet water security requirements. This tool could be moved to the Emergency Management category as well.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText:
"Water Utility Response On-The-Go is an innovative tool that consolidates information and tools that water utility operators and their response partners may need during an emergency. The tool is ideal for small systems that lack a large support network in place when natural disasters strike. Water Utility Response On-The-Go allows users to accomplish the following:
identify and contact emergency response partners monitor local and national severe weather conditions review and complete incident-specific checklists; and populate save and email both generic damage assessment forms and FEMA incident command system form"

Resource.ResourceName: Rule Making for Actions for Indian Country 5 Source Categories
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA finalized options to simplify the Clean Air Act permitting process for certain smaller sources for air pollution commonly found in Indian Country. The action will ensure that air quality in Indian country is protected by facilitating the implementation of the Federal Indian Country Minor New Source Review rule issued by EPA in July 2011. The action will impact 5 source categories.
Resource.CommentsText: Specific resource for permitting. Will require subject matter knowledge.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that provides information and options that simplify the Clean Air Act New Resource Review permitting process for certain minor sources of air pollution common to Indian country.

Resource.ResourceName: Rule Making for Actions for Indian Country 6 Source Categories
Resource.DescriptionText: On July 14, 2014, EPA proposed options to simplify the Clean Air Act permitting process for certain smaller sources of air pollution commonly found in Indian Country. This action would ensure that air quality in Indian Country is protected by facilitating the implementation of the Indian Country Minor Source New Source Review rule issued by EPA in July 2001. The action would impact 6 source categories.
Resource.CommentsText: Specific resource for permitting. Will require subject matter knowledge.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Rule making and simplifications explain for certain smaller sources of common air pollution.

Resource.DescriptionText: Grants and innovations in order to advance conservation and alternative energy use in agriculture. Database provides an easy to use search feature to query projects, grants, research, etc. Resources may help with conservation, planning, and alternative energy sources in agriculture.
Resource.CommentsText: Elected Officials
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Database provides an east to use search feature to query projects, grants, research documents in conservation and alternative energy use.

Resource.ResourceName: Safe Drinking Water Act: Consumer Confidence Reports (CCR)
Resource.DescriptionText: This website provides information on CCR, how utilities can submit the information electronically, and a host of other information to help utilities submit data to EPA. Also provides access to electronic submission of the CCR.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides downloadable guidance and can be accessed through the compliance help page.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides information on CCR, how utilities can submit information electronically, and provides access to the electronic submission of the CCR.

Resource.ResourceName: Sanitary Sewer Overflow Analysis and Planning (SSOAP) Toolbox
Resource.DescriptionText: Rainfall-derived infiltration and inflow (RDII) is the increased portion water flow in a sanitary sewer system that occurs during and after a rainfall as a source of operating problems in sanitary sewer systems. SSOAP toolbox is a suite of computer software tools used for the quantification of RDII and help capacity analysis and condition assessment of sanitary sewer systems. This toolbox includes the previous SWMM-5 for performing dynamic routing of flows through the sanitary sewer systems. Prediction methodology employed in the SSOAP toolbox offers an effective means to design a focused sewer condition assessment program and maximize success of field investigation efforts.
Resource.CommentsText: Determines RDII characteristics, prioritizes sewer sheds for sewer condition assessment, sewer rehabilitation, evaluates performance of sewer improvements, managing and analyzing flow monitoring and rainfall data.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: SSOAP toolbox is a suite of computer software tools used for the quantification of RDII and help capacity analysis and condition assessment of sanitary systems.

Resource.ResourceName: Security and Emergency Response Planning Toolbox for Small Water and Wastewater Systems
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for utilities to run table top exercise. Maybe better as a web tool to allow sharing of results. Older tool and more focused on training. EPA Water Security tools seem to be better and more available/newer. This tool is very small system focused.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Toolbox that consists of five core modules in relation to security and emergency planning.

Resource.DescriptionText: Allow citizens to connect with government. App allows local citizens to report possible disasters in order to get issues addressed quickly. Provides a series of reporting tools that are beneficial for analysis or potential problem areas. App connects governments and citizens in a quick and efficient fashion.
Resource.CommentsText: Reporting tool based on application to connect citizens with local government.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Application that allows local citizens to report possible disasters in order to get issues addressed quickly.

Resource.DescriptionText: EPA is one of 11 federal agencies that participate in the SBIR Program established by the Small Business Innovation Development Act of 1982. EPA issues annual solicitations for Phase I and Phase II research proposals from science and technology-based firms. Phase II contracts are limited to small businesses that have successfully completed their Phase I projects. Provides funding for innovative business ideas in relation to the environment.
Resource.CommentsText: Funding opportunities for research/innovation.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: EPA issues annual solicitations for Phase I and Phase II research proposals from science and technology based firms.

Resource.DescriptionText: Smart growth helps communities grow in ways that expand economic opportunity while protecting human health and the environment.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides a list of resources fir the future of smart growth for communities.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Smart growth helps communities grow in ways that expand economic opportunity while protecting human health and the environment.

Resource.ResourceName: Smart Growth Self-Assessment for Rural Communities
Resource.DescriptionText: The Smart Growth Self-Assessment for Rural Communities (2015) is a compilation of strategies, organized by 11 common "goal areas," that villages, towns, and small cities can use to evaluate their existing policies to create healthy, environmentally resilient, and economically robust places.
Resource.CommentsText: This self-assessment helps communities identify gaps in their policies, plans, codes, and zoning regulations by asking a series of "Yes" or "No" questions. All communities begin by completing the self-assessment's Revitalize Village and Town Centers section, which gives a baseline indication of smart growth development policies within the jurisdiction. It goes beyond regulatory issues to help communities take stock of their local initiatives, strategies, and plans.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Compilation of strategies organized by 11 common goal areas that communities can use to evaluate their policies.

Resource.DescriptionText: SolarRating Online uses information collected from over 1000 weather stations worldwide to assess the suitability of your home for solar technologies: photovoltaic (PV) to generate electricity and solar thermal for heating domestic hot water.
Resource.CommentsText: Assessment tool provides basic information relating to your location and roof angles on solar energy capacity.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool that uses data to determine the suitability of a home for solar technologies.

Resource.DescriptionText: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) was enacted by Congress in 1976 to protect human health and the environment from the potential hazards of waste disposal, conserve energy and natural resources, reduce the amount of waste generated, and ensure that wastes are managed in an environmentally sound manner.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource outlining Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA).

Resource.ResourceName: Solid and Hazardous Waste in Indian Country- Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA)
Resource.DescriptionText: Tribal governments may engage in solid waste management within their jurisdiction. Some tribes conduct waste management operations (e.g., waste collection and disposal) directly. Other tribes contract those services to private parties or enter into agreements with neighboring state or local governments. Proper management of solid waste is critical to public health and community.
Resource.CommentsText: Portal to more specific resources.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that provides information on RCRA solid waste management operations within Tribal government.

Resource.ResourceName: Source Water Protection Cost Benefit Analysis Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: This tool is designed to assist you in evaluating the triple bottom-line costs and benefits of different source water protection options. Cost/benefit calculations help evaluate, prioritize, justify, and ultimately implement source water protection initiatives.
Resource.CommentsText: Although a useful tool not many small utilities conduct triple bottom line analysis on source water. But it is simple to use and relatively straightforward for most audience.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool used to evaluate the triple bottom-line costs and benefits of different source water protection options.

Resource.DescriptionText: As a free service to the community, the St. Regis Air Program responds to any indoor air concern by asking a series of questions to determine potential potential sources of the indoor air issue, then schedules an appointment for technicians to visit the home. Generally, technicians rely upon sniffing monitors. They record levels of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, petroleum products, humidity, and temperature. All of these factors are relevant in trying to locate the nature of the problem. If a problem is found, the Program provides recommendations on how to correct the problem.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Free service to the community that responds to any indoor air concerns by asking a series of questions to determine potential sources of indoor air issues.
Resource.SourceSystemText: Saint Regis Mohawk Tribe Environment Division

Resource.DescriptionText: Hub for information on water body health.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Hub for information on water body health.

Resource.ResourceName: State-Specific Water Quality Standards Effective Under the Clean Water Act
Resource.DescriptionText: EPA has compiled state, territorial, and authorized tribal water quality standards that EPA has approved or are otherwise in effect for Clean Water Act purposes.
Resource.CommentsText: State specific.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: EPA has compiled state, territorial, and authorized tribal water quality standards that EPA has approved or are otherwise in effect for Clean Water Act purposes.

Resource.DescriptionText: Mining and mineral processing facilities generate more toxic and hazardous waste than any other industrial sector, costing billions of dollars to address the public health and environmental threats to communities. EPA will reduce the risk of mining waste contamination of drinking water, rivers, and streams, and work to cleanup mining sites across the nation. Map of mineral processing facilities.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use map that provides resources and information on mineral processing facilities.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that provides information on reducing the risk of mining waste contamination and clean up processes of drinking water, rivers, and streams.

Resource.DescriptionText: Used throughout world for planning, analysis and design related to Stormwater runoff, combined and sanitary sewers, and other drainage systems in urban areas. There are many applications for drainage systems in non-urban areas as well. Dynamic hydrology-hydraulic water quality simulation model. Used for single event or long-term simulation of runoff quantity and quality from primarily urban areas.
Resource.CommentsText: SWMM Climate Adjustment Tool allows future climate change projections to be incorporated into the Stormwater management model.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Planning, analysis, and design related to stormwater runoff, combined and sanitary sewers, and other drainage systems in urban areas.

Resource.ResourceName: Strategy for Reviewing Tribal Eligibility Applications to Administrator EPA Regulatory Programs
Resource.DescriptionText: The Strategy outlined in the memorandum is designed to improve both the TAS review process and ongoing communications with tribal TAS applicants. This Strategy is the product of an Agency-wide workgroup. To ensure that this Strategy considered the interests of tribes, EPA partnered with a tribal workgroup, organized by EPA's National Tribal Caucus, to obtain and provide tribal input. EPA also consulted with tribes on a government-to-government basis in developing this Strategy.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource and strategy to help Tribal communities in the TAS review process as well as improve communications with Tribal TAS applications and the EPA.

Resource.ResourceName: Summary of the Energy Policy Act
Resource.DescriptionText: Summary of the Energy Policy Act EPA.
Resource.CommentsText: Summary of the EPA energy requirements.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Summary of the Energy Policy Act EPA.

Resource.DescriptionText: SURF Your Watershed is at tool that draws from several databases to display information about the watershed for a given location: Watershed Name, SGS Cataloging Unit, Congressional Districts, Citizen-based Groups at work in this watershed (Provided by Adopt your Watershed), Water quality monitoring data from this watershed (Provided by STORET), Environmental Websites Involving this Watershed, Assessments of Watershed (link to WATERS, Information provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS), and Places Involving this Watershed.
Resource.CommentsText: After a basic search, provides a list of entities that are working to protect the searched watershed. Provides contact information as well as other basic links to click for more information.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Discover what organizations are working to protect specific watersheds.

Resource.DescriptionText:
"On June 16, 2009, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) joined together to help communities nationwide improve access to affordable housing, increase transportation options, and lower transportation costs while protecting the environment.
The Partnership for Sustainable Communities (PSC) works to coordinate federal housing, transportation, water, and other infrastructure investments to make neighborhoods more prosperous, allow people to live closer to jobs, save households time and money, and reduce pollution. The partnership agencies incorporate six principles of livability into federal funding programs, policies, and future legislative proposals."
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Designed to help communities nationwide improve access to affordable housing, increase transportation options, and lower transportation costs while protecting the environment.

Resource.ResourceName: System Inventory Services (formerly Registry of EPA Applications and Databases(READ))
Resource.DescriptionText: System Inventory Services (formerly Registry of EPA Applications, Models and Datasets (READ)) is the authoritative source of information about EPA information resources. Each information resource has a record in READ. Each record identifies if the information resource is an application/system, a dataset, or a model. The record also includes basic information about the resource such as Title, Acronym, Description, Contact information, and Organization. More detailed information also is available in a READ record, such as whether the resource supports a particular Governmental statute and, in the case of an application/system, how the application/system conforms to the Enterprise Architecture (EA). Life cycle information, user types, and access information are other data that can be found in a READ record.
Resource.CommentsText: Database and information for EPA Resources.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Database that provides resources on EPA information resources.

Resource.ResourceName: System for Urban Stormwater Treatment and Analysis Integration (SUSTAIN)
Resource.DescriptionText: A decision support system that assists stormwater management professionals with developing and implementing plans for flow and pollution control measures to protect source waters and meet water quality goals. SUSTAIN allows watershed and stormwater practitioners to develop, evaluate, and select optimal best management practice (BMP) combinations at various watershed scales based on cost and effectiveness.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Assists stormwater management professionals with developing and implementing plans for flow and pollution control measures to protect source waters and meet water quality goals.

Resource.DescriptionText: Database for training materials regarding brownfields and superfund sites. The training includes materials as well as in-person training courses. Users may search by criteria or region. Internet seminars are also offered.
Resource.CommentsText: Training database.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Database for training materials in relation to brownfields and superfund sites.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Redevelopment and Industrial Cleanup

Resource.DescriptionText: The TRI Program tracks the management of toxic chemicals that may pose a threat to human health and the environment. Facilities in certain industry sectors report annually the volume of toxic chemicals managed as waste--recycled, treated or burned for energy recovery--as well as disposed of or otherwise released into the environment. Select an option below to view TRI data.
Resource.CommentsText: Portal to more specific resources.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool to track and manage toxic chemicals that may pose a threat to human health and environment.

Resource.DescriptionText: Generates reports on releases, transfers, and wastes managed that can be compared across facilities, chemicals, geographic areas, industries (NAICS code), or reporting years. Includes ability to search data by tribal boundaries.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource to generate reports on releases, transfers, and waste managed that can be compared across facilities, chemicals, geographic areas, industries, or reporting years.

Resource.DescriptionText: TRI (Toxic Release Inventory) tracks the management of certain toxic chemicals that may pose a threat to human health and the environment. U.S. facilities in different industry sectors must report how much of each chemical is released to the environment and/or managed through recycling, energy recovery, and treatment. (A "release" of a chemical means that it is emitted to the air or water, or places in some type of land disposal.) The information submitted by facilities is compiled annually in the Toxics Release Inventory. TRI helps support informed decision-making by industry, government, non-governmental organizations and the public.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: U.S. facilities in different industry sectors must report how much of each chemical is released to the environment and/or managed through recycling, energy recovery and treatment.

Resource.DescriptionText: Build customized TRI data queries using menus or an ad-hoc query option. Users can download, map or overlay results with other data sources. This is a downloadable application that includes the ability to identify facilities that may be of interest to tribes.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Application that allows users to build customized TRI data queries using menus or an ad-hoc query option. Users can download, map, or overlay results with other data sources.

Resource.ResourceName: Tabletop Exercise Tool for Water Systems (TTX Tool)
Resource.DescriptionText:
"The PC-based Tabletop Exercise Tool for Water Systems: Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Climate Resiliency (TTX Tool) contains materials that assist those interested in planning and facilitating tabletop exercises that focus on water sector related issues.
This updated TTX Tool contains 15 scenarios that address an all-hazards approach to emergency preparedness and response. It addresses natural hazards and man-made incidents and introduces the potential impacts of climate change on the water sector."
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for utilities to run table top exercise. Maybe better as a web tool to allow sharing of results. Older tool.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool that contains materials that assist in planning and facilitating tabletop exercises that focus on water sector related issues.

Resource.DescriptionText: EPA's Targeted Brownfields Assessment (TBA) program is designed to help states, tribes, and municipalities especially those without EPA Brownfields assessment pilots/grants minimize the uncertainties of contamination often associated with Brownfields. Targeted Brownfields Assessments supplement and work with other efforts under EPA's Brownfields program to promote the cleanup and redevelopment of brownfields.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides a series of workbooks, information, and assessment guidelines depending on the region.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: EPA's Targeted Brownfields Assessment (TBA) program is designed to help states, tribes, and municipalities especially those without EPA Brownfields assessment pilots/grants minimize the uncertainties of contamination often associated with Brownfields.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Redevelopment and Industrial Cleanup
Resource.BusinessFunctionText: Financial Assistance|Nutrients and Pollution Reduction|Technical Guidance

Resource.DescriptionText: A Technical Assistance Grant (TAG) helps communities participate in Superfund cleanup decision-making. It provides funding to community groups to contract their own technical adviser to interpret and explain technical reports, site conditions, and EPAs proposed cleanup proposals and decisions. An initial grant up to $50,000 is available to qualified community groups.
Resource.CommentsText: Grant that provides assistance to communities to understand the complexities that come with superfund sites.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Assists communities in allowing them to participate in Superfund cleanup decision-making.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Redevelopment and Industrial Cleanup

Resource.DescriptionText: Explore maps and graphs of historical and projected climate trends in your local area. View data by topics to see how climate change will impact the things you care about.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Explore maps and graphs of historical and projected climate trends in your local area. View data by topics to see how climate change will impact things you care about.

Resource.DescriptionText: EM-DAT provides an objective basis for vulnerability assessment and rational decision-making in disaster situations. For example, it helps policymakers identify disaster types that are most common in a given country and have had significant historical impacts on specific human populations.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use database that provides international information on a specific set of disasters.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides and objective basis for vulnerability assessment and rational decision-making in disaster situations.

Resource.DescriptionText: Provides a list of tools for stormwater management and how to implement those tools. Rain gardens, Grassed Swales, Pervious Pavement, Parking Lots, Bio retention Basins, Underground Storage, Green Roofs, Rain Barrels, Stream Buffers. Each link gives the user a description on how to apply the specific tool and implement it in real world situations
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: List of tools for stormwater management and how to implement those tools.

Resource.DescriptionText: Approaches for reducing greenhouse gases from transportation include using low greenhouse gas fuels, improving vehicle technologies, reducing the number of vehicle miles traveled, and operating vehicles more efficiently. In combination, system approaches that combine these strategies can reduce transportation-related emissions significantly. This page gives a variety of different information regarding strategies and analysis to deal with transportation and climate change.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resources that provide information for reducing greenhouse gasses from transportation.

Resource.DescriptionText: EPA and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) are taking coordinated steps to enable the production of a new generation of clean vehicles, through reduced greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and improved fuel use from on-road vehicles and engines, from the smallest cars to the largest trucks.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource providing information on transportation and climate regulation.

Resource.DescriptionText: A listing of treatment technologies available to drinking and wastewater utilities
Resource.CommentsText: Although a good reference guide it does not provide any guidance on how to select a technology.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: A listing of treatment technologies available to drinking and wastewater utilities

Resource.DescriptionText: The Tribal Authority Rule implements the provisions of section 301(d) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) authorizing eligible tribes to implement their own tribal air programs. This resource will provide Tribes with the proper information for their situation.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resources and information on the Tribal Authority Rule that authorize eligible tribes to implement their own tribal air programs.

Resource.DescriptionText: Sustainable design to assist tribal communities to reduce the impact of construction on the environment while protecting the health, livelihood and the culture of tribal residents. The toolkit is designed to help tribal officials, community members, planners, developers, and architects develop and adopt building codes to support green building practices.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use toolkit to help in the sustainable development of tribal communities.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Sustainable design in order to assist tribal communities in reducing the impact of construction on the environment, while protecting health, and culture of residents.

Resource.DescriptionText: Congress established the New Source Review (NSR) permitting program as part of the 1977 Clean Air Act Amendments. NSR is a preconstruction permitting program that serves two important purposes. First, it ensures that air quality is not significantly degraded from the addition of new and modified sources such as factories, industrial boilers and power plants. In areas with unhealthy air, NSR assures that new emissions do not slow progress toward a cleaner air. In areas with clean air, especially pristine areas such as national parks, NSR assures people that any large new or modified industrial source in their neighborhoods will be as clean as possible, and that the advances in pollution control occur concurrently with industrial expansion.
Resource.CommentsText: Portal to more specific resources.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Air quality permitting information and program that serves important information.

Resource.DescriptionText: EPA's Tribal ecoAmbassadors Program partners EPA scientists with Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCU) professors to address environmental problems. The Tribal ecoAmbassadors Program has given more that 150 TCU students the opportunity to work directly with their professors and EPA scientists.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: The Tribal ecoAmbassadors Program has given more than 150 TCU students the opportunity to work directly with their professors and EPA scientists.
Resource.VersionNotesText: The Tribal ecoAmbassadors Program has given more than 150 TCU students the opportunity to work directly with their professors and EPA scientists.
Resource.TopicText: Emerging Technologies, Issues and Topics|Finance and Grants

Resource.DescriptionText: EPA's brownfields program provides direct funding for brownfields assessment, cleanup, revolving loans, and environmental job training. To facilitate the leveraging of public resources, EPA's Brownfields Program collaborates with other EPA programs, other federal partners, and state agencies to identify and make available resources that can be used for brownfields activities. In addition to direct brownfields funding, EPA also provides technical information on brownfields financing matters.
Resource.CommentsText: Funding Opportunities/guidance on funding opportunities.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Funding provided for brownfield assessment, cleanup, revolving loans, and environmental job training.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Redevelopment and Industrial Cleanup|Finance and Grants

Resource.DescriptionText: Every community and business faces some risk of climate-related disruptions to their operations. For some, it is not a question of "if" but "when" disruptions will occur. Anticipating potential problems and preparing to prevent or respond to them can make it easier to bounce back from disruptions.
Resource.CommentsText: East to use step by step guide to identify the problem, understand vulnerabilities, find alternatives, and eventually take action.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Toolkit for community and businesses to prepare for climate related disruptions.

Resource.ResourceName: Underground Storage Tanks (USTs) Laws and Regulations
Resource.DescriptionText: A complete version of the law that governs underground storage tanks (USTs) is available in the U.S. Code, Title 42, Chapter 82, Subchapter IX. This law incorporates amendments to Subtitle I of the Solid Waste Disposal Act as well as the UST provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 and gives EPA the authority to regulate USTs.
Resource.CommentsText: Laws and Regulations.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that provides information on a specific law that incorporates amendments to the Solid Waste Disposal Act as well as provisions to the Energy Policy Act of 2005.

Resource.ResourceName: United States Coast Guard National Response Center
Resource.DescriptionText: List of national response reports through the years. Also provides a national response phone number available to anyone that witnesses a spill, chemical release, or security incident.
Resource.CommentsText: Database and contact information for maritime emergencies.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: List of national response reports through the years. Also provides a national response phone number available to anyone that witnesses a spill, chemical release, or security incident.

Resource.DescriptionText: Sustainability of waste management is key to providing an effective service that satisfies the needs of the end users. One pillar of sustainable solid waste management is strategic planning, and links to guidance are provided. Another pillar is cost analysis of solid waste options, and links to useful analytical tools are also provided. For financing, private sector involvement is a growing trend in solid waste management.
Resource.CommentsText: provides a variety of different resources.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides information on strategic planning and cost analysis of waste management systems.

Resource.ResourceName: Ventilation Checklist from Indoor Air Quality Tools for School
Resource.DescriptionText: Adequate air ventilation is a vital part of ensuring good IAQ. Facilities and maintenance staff can use this checklist to help examine: outdoor air intakes, system cleanliness, outdoor, air supplies, air distribution, exhaust systems, quantity of outdoor air.
Resource.CommentsText: Provides a checklist for officials to review when testing and reviewing indoor air quality. Easy to use.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Checklist used to help examine outdoor air intakes, system cleanliness, outdoor air supplies, air distribution, exhaust systems, and quantity of outdoor air.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIM / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: The Verification Program evaluates the emission reduction performance and durability of specific retrofit technologies when submitted by manufacturers. The verification process includes a thorough technical review and tightly controlled testing to quantify levels of emission reductions and identify engine operating criteria and conditions that must be met for technologies to achieve those reductions.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Evaluates the emission reduction performance and durability of specific retrofit technologies when submitted by manufacturers.

Resource.DescriptionText: General Information regarding the emerging Technology Process. Helps users classify what an emerging technology actually is.
Resource.CommentsText: Information for classifying emerging technologies.

Resource.DescriptionText: VSAT Version 6.0 complies with the water sector risk assessment standard and can offer liability protection under the Department of Homeland Security's Support Anti-Terrorism by Fostering Effective Technologies (SAFETY) Act program. EPA strongly encourages drinking water and wastewater utility owners and operators to use VSAT 6.0 to conduct or update an all-hazards risk assessment.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool that complies with the water sector risk assessment standard and can offer liability protection under the Department of Homeland Security.
Resource.TopicText: Drinking Water and Wastewater|Natural Disaster and Emergency Management

Resource.ResourceName: WAWTTAR (Water and Wastewater Treatment Technologies Appropriate for Reuse)
Resource.DescriptionText: WAWTTAR is a predictive program intended to assist planners in selecting suitable water and wastewater treatment options appropriate to the material and manpower resources available to particular communities throughout the world. WAWTTAR is designed to assist in alleviating the problem of overlooking good processes alternatives for water and wastewater treatment, and also help screen out treatment technologies which are inappropriate for given locales and situations.
Resource.CommentsText: This would be a better tool if it was updated more frequently. Treatment options tools seem to be limited.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Predictive program to assist planners in selecting water and wastewater treatment options appropriate to the material and manpower resources available to particular communities through the world.

Resource.ResourceName: WEPPCAT: Online Tool for Assessing and Managing the Potential Impacts of Climate Change on Sediment Loading to Streams Using the Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP) Model.
Resource.DescriptionText: WEPPCAT is an on-line tool that provides a flexible capability for creating user-determined climate change scenarios for assessing the potential impacts of climate change on sediment loading to streams using the USDA's Water Erosion Prediction Project (WEPP) Model. In combination with the existing capabilities of WEPP for assessing the effectiveness of management practices, WEPPCAT also can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of strategies for managing the impacts of climate change.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool that provides a flexible capability for creating user-determined climate change scenarios for assessing the potential impacts of climate change on sediment loading to streams.

Resource.DescriptionText:
This website has an intuitive and user-friendly set of on-line process and practice guidlines, templates and decision support tools that will: - Simplify the development of consistent Total Asset Management Plans - Provide effective Implementation Guidelines for agencies to asses and drive meaningful improvements in asset management.
The users of this website will be: - Asset managers and operators - State and federal regulators - Appointed and elected officials - Engineering consultants - Managers and owners of contract operation firms.
Resource.CommentsText: A complete asset management system for small utilities. The toolset includes training, the system, and technical assistance.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Resource that will simplify the development of consistent Total Asset Management Plans and provide effective implementation guidelines for agencies.
Resource.SourceSystemText: Sustainable Infrastructure Management Program Learning Environment (SIMPLE)

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIM / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: This calculator provides the user with a series of questions regarding soil, air, or tap water readings. It will require the user to have specific chemical data regarding these topics. The user will select a list of individual chemicals as well as their levels. The calculator will then provide the safe amount for all age levels.
Resource.CommentsText: User will need to have specific chemical information in order to retrieve active results. However, you are able to do a generic search of specific chemicals to see their levels of safety.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Calculator that provides user with a series of questions regarding soil, air, or tap water readings.
Resource.TopicText: Brownfields and Redevelopment and Industrial Cleanup

Resource.DescriptionText: EPA enforces a variety of environmental requirements related to pollution by waste and chemicals. For more on EPA's enforcement process visit this link. There are a variety of resources regarding cleanup and treatment.

Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Environmental requirements in relation to pollution by waste and chemicals.

Resource.DescriptionText: This section provides policy and guidance documents related to the enforcement related to pollution by waste, chemical and cleanup sites.

Resource.ShortDescriptionText: This section provides policy and guidance documents related to the enforcement related to pollution by waste, chemical and cleanup sites.
