Resource.ResourceName: Water Health and Economic Analysis Tool (WHEAT)
Resource.DescriptionText: The tool is designed to assist drinking water utility owners and operators in quantifying public health impacts, utility financial costs, and regional economic impacts of an adverse event, based on a variety of asset-threat combinations that pose a risk to the water sector. Existing WHEAT modules currently analyze two event scenarios the release of a hazardous gas and the loss of operating assets in a drinking water distribution system - and provide information that can be used as part of a comprehensive risk assessment
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool designed to assist drinking water utility owners and operators in quantifying public health impacts, financial costs, and regional economic impacts of adverse events.
Resource.TopicText: Drinking Water and Wastewater|Natural Disaster and Emergency Management
Resource.BusinessFunctionText: Nutrients and Pollution Reduction|Technical Guidance|Water Security

Resource.ResourceName: Water Infrastructure and Resiliency Finance Center
Resource.DescriptionText:
"Leading edge financing and increased resiliency are key components to meeting water infrastructure needs. The Water Infrastructure and Resiliency Finance Center is a resource to communities that are financing drinking water, wastewater, and stormwater infrastructure.
The Center is working to: - Promote innovative financing approaches. The center encourages effective use of federal, state, and local funds and works with the private sector, where appropriate, to build partnerships to increase water infrastructure investment. - Support and expand capacity building efforts through collaborative technical assistance. The center works with states, communities, universities, and non-profits to help utilities explore financing options for their local needs. The center provides information for developing sustainable funding sources for water efficiency, energy efficiency, water reuse, stormwater, and green infrastructure."
Resource.CommentsText: Primarily provides links to finance and is not really a tool. Good website that provides excellent information to drive innovation.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Finance resource for communities that are financing drinking water, wastewater, and stormwater infrastructure.
Resource.TopicText: Drinking Water and Wastewater|Finance and Grants

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIM / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: Provides an outlines the business case for investment in new tools in the most promising market opportunities of the water quality sector. Technology innovation can help address the water challenges and help put a more sustainable path while supporting economic growth.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Provides a business case for investment in new tools in the most promising market opportunities of the water quality sector.

Resource.DescriptionText: This model helps users interpret and predict water quality responses to natural phenomena and manmade pollution for various pollution management decisions. WASP is a dynamic compartment-modeling program for aquatic systems, including both the water column and the underlying benthos. WASP is one of the most widely used water quality models in the United States. Widely applied in the development of Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDL). Has capabilities of linking with hydrodynamic and watershed models which allows for multi-year analysis under varying meteorological and environmental conditions.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Interpret and predict water quality response to natural phenomena and manmade pollution for various pollution management decisions.

Resource.DescriptionText: To support water quality standards development, we offer the Water Quality Standards Academy (WQSA), which presents classroom-based and online courses, along with occasional satellite broadcasts.
Resource.CommentsText: Training materials for water quality standards and monitoring,
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Classroom based as well as online courses that support water quality standards development.

Resource.ResourceName: Water Utility Customer Assistance Program Cost Estimation Tool
Resource.DescriptionText: This tool was developed to help utilities assess the costs and benefits of implementing a customer affordability program in their service area. Using information from the U.S. Census Bureau and water and wastewater rates inputted by the user, this interactive instrument incorporates information about the eligibility threshold to qualify for an affordability program, annual assistance offered per customer, percent of customers responsible for bad debt, among other fields.
Resource.CommentsText: Good tool for setting up rate programs for rural or low income areas. Simple to use.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool used to help utilities assess the costs and benefits of implementing a customer affordability program in their service area.

Resource.DescriptionText: Apple App for mobile devices. This application is ideal for Users of all ages where they can learn about water quality parameters such as Dissolved Oxygen, E. coli, pH, Nutrients, Turbidity and much more. Students can gather data about their field study site in a site profile. The Benthic Macro invertebrates section acts as a field guide of all of the major taxa used to calculate pollution tolerance indexes. Pictures, sketches and descriptions for identification are included for twenty-two macro invertebrates. Scientists and citizen science groups can use the Water Quality app to learn about water quality parameters and to collect chemical and biological data from their study sites. Data is organized in reports and can be printed or submitted to the River on the Web database.
Resource.CommentsText: This application is a pay to use application. It costs $4.99 on the iTunes Application store.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Mobile application that informs users about water quality parameters such as dissolved oxygen, E. Coli, pH, nutrients, turbidity, and much more.

Resource.DescriptionText: WaterWatch is a USGS website with valuable resources regarding water quality. Waterwatch gives a variety of different reports typically updated on a daily basis. Each report has a specific number of parameters that can be implemented.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Valuable resources regarding water quality reports updated on a daily basis.

Resource.DescriptionText:
Watershed Academy Web, is the program's distance learning program. The website offers a variety of self-paced training modules that represent a basic and broad introduction to the watershed management field. The modules are organized by the six themes listed below.
- Introductory/Overview Modules - Watershed Ecology Modules - Watershed Change Modules - Analysis and Planning Modules - Management Practices Modules - Community and Social Modules - Water Law Modules
Resource.CommentsText: Not a tool but a set of training modules used that can be available to utilities. Updated frequently and probably one of the most comprehensive sets of EPA training.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Offers a variety of self-paced training modules that represent a basic and broad introduction to the watershed management field.

Resource.DescriptionText: The tool is designed for users who are involved in watershed management activities. These activities include the development and implementation of watershed plans, the analysis of data and the implementation of management practices.
Resource.CommentsText: Application can be used to plan and analyze watersheds. Allows for user to save and load previous plans. Powered by ESRI.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Tool designed for users involved in watershed management activities.

Resource.DescriptionText: Provides a basic hub for wetlands protection and restoration.
Resource.CommentsText: Hub location to start the process of finding more information on wetlands restoration.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Basic hub for wetlands protection and restoration.

Resource.DescriptionText: List of definitions and distinctions for wetlands restoration.
Resource.CommentsText: Easy to use list of definitions.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: List of definitions and distinctions for wetlands restoration.

Resource.DescriptionText: The Climate Change, Wildlife and Wildlands Toolkit for Formal and Informal Educators is an updates and expanded version of the award-winning and very popular Climate Change, Wildlife and Wildlands Toolkit for Teachers and Interpreters, which was first published in 2001. The kit is designed for classroom teachers and informal educators in parks, refuges, forest lands, nature centers, zoos, aquariums, science centers, etc., and is aimed at the middle school grade level.
Resource.CommentsText: Highly recommended for students.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Toolkit for formal and informal educators that provides educational materials for a variety of different situations.

Resource.DescriptionText: The DataFinder is an app for accessing data on global development indicators from The World Bank Group.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: The DataFinder is an app for accessing data on global development indicators from The World Bank Group.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OEI / OIM / IESD - Information Exchange and Services Division
Resource.DescriptionText: Map out your customizable project and receive basic capacity, energy yield, revenue and system displacement data. Map site, plot site, configure set, and analyze the site data. The tool provides a basic tool as well as an advanced tool. Each tool requires the user to log in.
Resource.CommentsText: Tool provides a great deal of information on the possibility of using solar for particular locations. Tool allows the use to select locations.
Resource.ShortDescriptionText: Map customizable project with results on basic capacity, energy yield, revenue and system displacement data.

Resource.PrimaryOrganizationText: EPA / OLEM - Office of Land and Emergency Management
Resource.DescriptionText:
See how much enegy is saved when you recycle an item, and the common household item that energy can power.
Add the iWARM widget to your Web page. The widget helps users on your Web site understand how much energy is saved through recycling, and lets them share their results. The iWARM widget displays energy-saving benefits of recycling. This is the widget-version of the iWARM, which helps consumers understand the energy saved by recycling small quantities of common household products, rather than landfilling them. The energy savings are translated into the equivalent amount of electricity, estimating how long that amount of electricity will operate a variety of household appliances.
Resource.CommentsText:
The iWARM widget displays energy-saving benefits of recycling. This is the widget-version of the iWARM, which helps consumers understand the energy saved by recycling small quantities of common household products, rather than landfilling them. The energy savings are translated into the equivalent amount of electricity, estimating how long that amount of electricity will operate a variety of household appliances.
The energy calculations are based on the Waste Reduction Model (WARM), which was created to help solid waste planners and organizations track greenhouse gas emissions reductions from several different waste management practices. For information on the data and methodologies behind the calculations, please see the model documentation.
You can share your calculation results on Twitter or Facebook, or embed the widget on your own website. There are two variations of the widget that are available for use. The widget can be added to a variety of web pages. If you need help in adding a widget to your Web page, please contact your webmaster or service provider.
Easy to use widget that can be downloaded to use in Excel or added to a webpage. The code is provided.
